async-story.text: The Waiting Problem. In synchronous code, each operation blocks until it completes. Get user data—wait. Get orders—wait. Get reviews—wait. Your total time is the sum of all waiting.
Blocking I/O. Most of that waiting isn't CPU work—it's I/O. Database calls, API requests, file reads. Your program sits idle while waiting for responses.
Async to the Rescue. Asynchronous code doesn't wait. Start all three requests at once, and your total time becomes the maximum of any single request, not the sum!
Concurrent Execution. With async await and gather, you can fire off multiple operations simultaneously. While one waits for the database, another waits for the API—all at once.
The Scale Impact. At scale, this is the difference between handling one thousand and ten thousand requests per second. Same operations, same hardware, dramatically better throughput!

events-story.text: The Coupling Problem. In request-response architecture, services call each other directly and wait. Order service calls payment, which calls inventory, which calls shipping. One chain, all waiting.
Publish-Subscribe. Event-driven flips this model. Services publish events to a message queue. Other services subscribe to events they care about. No direct calls, no waiting!
Decoupling Benefits. Services don't need to know about each other. Add a new analytics consumer? Just subscribe to the events. No changes to the producer needed.
Built-In Resilience. If a consumer is down, messages wait in the queue. No data lost. When the consumer recovers, it processes the backlog. The system self-heals!
Instant User Response. Best of all, you respond to users immediately. 'Order confirmed!' Then payment, inventory, and shipping process in the background. Users love fast responses!

patterns-story.text: Failure is Inevitable. In production, things fail. Networks hiccup, services crash, databases timeout. Your code must handle failure gracefully, not just hope it doesn't happen.
Retry with Backoff. When a call fails, retry—but not immediately! Wait two seconds, then four, then eight. Exponential backoff gives the failing service time to recover.
Dead Letter Queue. After max retries, don't lose the message. Send it to a dead letter queue for investigation. Ops can debug why it failed and replay it later.
Circuit Breaker. If a service is down, stop hammering it! After five failures, the circuit opens—requests fail fast. After thirty seconds, try one request. Success? Circuit closes.
Graceful Degradation. Together, these patterns let your system degrade gracefully under failure. Some features may be unavailable, but the core keeps running. That's production-grade reliability!
